column1: '''Certhas Daeron''' is the name of the standardization that [[Daeron]] performed in the ancient [[Cirth]] during the [[First Age]].

column2: WJ}}, [[The Grey Annals]]</ref>, Dairon (better known as [[Daeron]]), the Minstrel and Loremaster of [[Doriath]], reorganised the cirth and added new ones, making the extension of the cirth known as Certhas Daeron, used for inscribing names in [[Menegroth]]. The [[Dwarves]] working for [[Thingol]] liked them and adopted them, making them known also in the East, beyond the [[Blue Mountains]].

column1: The nature and the timeframe of the standardization however are obscure; some point the similarities between q et 1 with 1 and 8 as signs that Daeron was influenced by the [[Tengwar]], therefore this mustn't had occurred before the return of the [[Noldor]]. Unlike the previous system, the reversal of the certh had a phonemic significance: reversed cirth were softer versions of their originals. This also gives us another information: perhaps [[prestanneth
column2: lenited]] consonants must have started to occur in Sindarin around that time.

column1: We know that at one time a sound of ''mh'' (soft ''m'') was needed at some later time<ref>{{HM
column2: AE}} and the most appropriate solution was to revert the certh for ''m'' to indicate its softening, but it could not be reverted (presumably it was the certh 5); therefore ''m'' was given to 6 (which until then had a value unknown to us), and 5 got the value of ''hw''.

column1: The same process took place with ''r'', ''l'' etc..
Maybe at that time, also the distinct cirth for semivowels and umlauts (sounds like ''w'', ''y'' and ''œ''), were employed.
